fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The category of sets Set is the category whose objects are sets and whose morphisms are set-functions.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category theory in context

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suitable for advanced undergraduates and graduate students in mathematics, the text provides tools for understanding and attacking difficult problems in algebra, number theory, algebraic geometry, and algebraic topology. Drawing upon a broad range of mathematical examples from the categorical perspective, the author illustrates how the concepts and constructions of category theory arise from and illuminate more basic mathematical ideas. Prerequisites are limited to familiarity with some basic set theory and logic.
A (pre)set is a collection of some pre-mathematical elements. We write x\in X to denote that x is an element of the set X.
A (set-)function consists of two sets, the domain and the codomain, and a rule (say, a derivation) that assigns to each element of the domain a unique element of the codomain.
The category of sets Set is the category whose objects are sets and whose morphisms are set-functions.

fr:title.text: Elementary theory of the category of sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Elementary theory of the category of sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Lawvere's elementary theory of the category of sets asserts that the category of sets is the well-pointed topos with choice and a natural numbers object.
An injection is a monomorhpism in Set. Explicitly, a map A\xrightarrow {f} B is injective if, for every x,y\in A, f(x)=f(y) implies x=y.
An surjection is an epimorphism in Set. Explicitly, a map A\xrightarrow {f} B is surjective if, for every y\in B, there exists an x\in A such that f(x)=y.
A bijection is an isomorphism in Set. Explicitly, a map is bijective if it is both injective and surjective.
A subset is a subobject in Set. Notationally, it is specified as \{x\in X: \phi (x)\}, where \phi (x) is the classifying map of the subobject.
The empty set \varnothing is the initial object in Set. Explicitly, it is the set with no elements.
The singleton set * is the terminal object in Set. Explicitly, it is the set with one element.
The cartesian product is the product in Set. Explicitly, the product of sets A and B is A\times B = \{(a, b) \mid a\in A, b\in B\}.
The disjoint union is the coproduct in Set. Explicitly, the disjoint union of sets A and B is A \sqcup B = \{(a, 0) \mid a \in A\} \cup \{(b, 1) \mid b \in B\}, where \cup denotes the union.
An equivalence relation is a congruence in Set. Explicitly, it is a reflexive, symmetric, and transitive relation.
The quotient of a set X by an equivalence relation \sim is the set of equivalence classes of \sim , i.e. \{\{x: x\sim x_0\}: x_0\in X\}.
Set is complete.

By the completeness criterion, it suffices to give products and equalizers. Products are given by the cartesian product. The equalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows }B is \{a\in A: f(a) = b(a)\}.

Let J\xrightarrow {D} Set be a small diagram. We define \operatorname *{lim} D = \operatorname *{Cone}_D(*) = \operatorname {Hom}(*, D), where * is the constant functor at the singleton and \operatorname *{Cone} is the cone functor. Note that this is indeed a set, because J is small. An element of this set is a natural transformation *\xrightarrow {\mu } D, which consists of a morphism *\xrightarrow {\mu _j} Dj for each j\in J, hence canonically identifies a J-tuple of elements (x_i\in Dj). The legs of should be maps \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } Dj; we define these by (*\xrightarrow {\mu } D)\xmapsto {\lambda _j} \mu _j(*).

To show that this cone is limiting, let Z\xrightarrow {
u } D be a cone. We need to show that 
u factors uniquely through \lambda . An element z\in Z identifies a map *	o Z, and hence a cone *	o Z\xrightarrow {
u } D, which is thus an element t(z)\in \operatorname *{lim} D. Now \lambda _j(t(z)) = (
u z)_j = 
u _j(z), and so 
u = \lambda t, as desired. It remains to show uniqueness, but any function Z\xrightarrow {u} \operatorname *{lim} D factoring 
u must satisfy u(z)_j = \lambda _j(u(z)) = 
u _j(z) = (
u z)_j = t(z)_j, so we are done.
Set is cocomplete.

By the cocompleteness criterion, it suffices to give coproducts and coequalizers. Coproducts are given by the disjoint union. The coequalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows } B is B / \sim , where \sim is the equivalence relation generated by f(a) \sim g(a) for all a \in A, and / denotes the quotient of sets.
The natural numbers \mathbb {N} = \{0, 1, \dots \} are the natural numbers object in Set.

The integers \mathbb {Z} = \{\dots , -1, 0, 1, \dots \} are the quotient of the square \mathbb {N}\times \mathbb {N} of the natural numbers by the relation (n, m)\sim (n', m') \text { iff } n + m' = n' + m.

The rational numbers \mathbb {Q} are the quotient of the product \mathbb {Z}\times \mathbb {Z}\setminus 0 of the integers with the integers without zero by the relation (p, q)\sim (p', q')\text { iff } pq' = qp'.
A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
Categories are ubiquitous in mathematics, as the following examples show.
The category of sets Set is the category whose objects are sets and whose morphisms are set-functions.
The category of relations Rel has sets as objects and relations as morphisms. Composition is given by existence, i.e. a (SR) c if and only if there is some b such that aRb and bRc.
The category of topological spaces Top is the category whose objects are topological spaces and whose morphisms are continuous functions.
The category of groups Grp is the category whose objects are groups and whose morphisms are homomorphisms.
We call these examples concrete. However, as the following examples show, not all categories look like this.
The empty category is the category with no objects and no morphisms.
The trivial category is the category with one object and only its identity morphism.

A preorder is a category P in which, for each pair of objects x and y, P(x, y) is either empty or a singleton. Explicitly, this means that it has a collection of elements (its objects) and a reflexive, transitive relation (inhabitance of hom-sets).
For any ordinal \alpha , there is a preorder whose objects are the smaller ordinals with the usual order.
A monoid can be thought of as a category with one object, whose morphisms are the elements of the monoid and whoses composition is the operation.
By the connection between monoids and categories, a group is a groupoid with one object.

An explicit construction is as follows: given a set A, we let \mathcal {F} A be the set of finitely supported formal \mathbb {Z}-linear combinations \sum _{a\in A} c_a a in A, with pointwise addition.

The regular coimage of a map x\xrightarrow {f} y is always a quotient, which we write x/\ker f. The inuition is that the kernel pair is (in Set-like settings) like the set of pairs of elements of x which agree in y, and so the coequalizer is like the set of nonempty fibers of f.

fr:title.text: Filtered colimits commute with finite limits in Set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Filtered colimits commute with finite limits in Set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Filtered colimits commute with finite limits in Set (and the result extends to \kappa -filtered and \kappa -small limits).
The empty set \varnothing is the initial object in Set. Explicitly, it is the set with no elements.
The singleton set * is the terminal object in Set. Explicitly, it is the set with one element.
An action of G on A is equivalently a functor from the associated category to G to Set which sends the unique object of G to A.
As for any monadic category, Grp is complete, and moreover its limits are created from Set.
By the general adjoint functor theorem, the forgetful functor Grp \xrightarrow {U} Set admits a left adjoint, called the free group functor.

The forgetful functor creates limits, by a straightforward diagram chase. Moreover, for any set x, a solution set consists of (the isomorphism classes of) those groups with sufficiently small cardinalities so that they may be generated by the image of x into some UG. Indeed, because x has some fixed cardinality, this set is (essentially) small.

A (left) action of a group G on a set X is a homomorphism from G to the automorphism group of X. By uncurrying in Set, this is equivalently a map G\times X\xrightarrow {\cdot } X so that e\cdot x = x \text { and }(gh)\cdot x = g\cdot (h\cdot x). A set equipped with a G-action is called a G-set.

fr:title.text: Elementary theory of the category of sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Elementary theory of the category of sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Lawvere's elementary theory of the category of sets asserts that the category of sets is the well-pointed topos with choice and a natural numbers object.

fr:title.text: Presheaf categories are complete and cocomplete

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Presheaf categories are complete and cocomplete

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every presheaf category is complete and cocomplete, with limits and colimits computed as in Set.
Limits and colimits are computed pointwise and Set is complete and cocomplete.
The map *\xrightarrow {\top } \{0, 1\}; *\mapsto 1 is a subobject classifier in Set.
A subset is a subobject in Set. Notationally, it is specified as \{x\in X: \phi (x)\}, where \phi (x) is the classifying map of the subobject.
A cartesian category C satisfies the following equations up to natural isomorphism:
By the representability of limits, each of these follows from the corresponding result in Set.

Let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a diagram in a locally small category C whose limit exists. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(x, \operatorname *{lim} F)\cong \operatorname *{lim} C(x, F-), where the latter is a limit in Set.
Dually, let the colimit of F exist. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} F, x)\cong \operatorname *{lim}_{J^\text {op}} C(F-, x).
Set is complete.

By the completeness criterion, it suffices to give products and equalizers. Products are given by the cartesian product. The equalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows }B is \{a\in A: f(a) = b(a)\}.

Let J\xrightarrow {D} Set be a small diagram. We define \operatorname *{lim} D = \operatorname *{Cone}_D(*) = \operatorname {Hom}(*, D), where * is the constant functor at the singleton and \operatorname *{Cone} is the cone functor. Note that this is indeed a set, because J is small. An element of this set is a natural transformation *\xrightarrow {\mu } D, which consists of a morphism *\xrightarrow {\mu _j} Dj for each j\in J, hence canonically identifies a J-tuple of elements (x_i\in Dj). The legs of should be maps \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } Dj; we define these by (*\xrightarrow {\mu } D)\xmapsto {\lambda _j} \mu _j(*).

To show that this cone is limiting, let Z\xrightarrow {
u } D be a cone. We need to show that 
u factors uniquely through \lambda . An element z\in Z identifies a map *	o Z, and hence a cone *	o Z\xrightarrow {
u } D, which is thus an element t(z)\in \operatorname *{lim} D. Now \lambda _j(t(z)) = (
u z)_j = 
u _j(z), and so 
u = \lambda t, as desired. It remains to show uniqueness, but any function Z\xrightarrow {u} \operatorname *{lim} D factoring 
u must satisfy u(z)_j = \lambda _j(u(z)) = 
u _j(z) = (
u z)_j = t(z)_j, so we are done.
The cartesian product is the product in Set. Explicitly, the product of sets A and B is A\times B = \{(a, b) \mid a\in A, b\in B\}.

A cocone (or just cone) under a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C with nadir c\in C is a natural transformation D\xrightarrow {\lambda } c, where c is the constant functor at c. Explicitly, a cone consists of, for each object j\in J, a morphism Dj\xrightarrow {\lambda _j} c, so that for each morphism j\xrightarrow {f}k\in J, the following diagram commutes:
The components \lambda _j of the cocone are called its colegs or just legs.

A cone over a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C with apex c\in C is a natural transformation c\xrightarrow {\lambda } D, where c is the constant functor at c. Explicitly, a cone consists of, for each object j\in J, a morphism c\xrightarrow {\lambda _j} Dj, so that for each morphism j\xrightarrow {f}k\in J, the following diagram commutes:
The components \lambda _j of the cone are called its legs.

fr:title.text: Universal elements are initial or terminal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Universal elements are initial or terminal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A (covariant) functor C\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if and only if its category of elements \text {el}(F) has a initial object. Dually, a presheaf C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if and only if its category of elements has a terminal object.

First let c\in C represent F, so that there is a natural isomorphism C(c, -)\overset {\alpha }{\cong } F. Then the pair (c, \alpha _c(1_c)) is initial in \text {el}(F). Indeed, for any (d, y)\in \text {el}(F), the bijection \alpha _d determines a unique element f\in C(c, d) so that Ff(\alpha _c(1_c)) = y; this exactly expresses initiality.

Conversely, let (c, x) be initial in \text {el}(F). By the Yoneda lemma, the element x\in Fc determines a natural transformation C(c, -)\xrightarrow {\Phi (x)} F; we need to show this is an isomorphism. Initiality of (c, x) asserts that, for any (d, y)\in \text {el}(F), there is a unique map c\xrightarrow {f_y} d such that Ff_y(x) = y. Now in the proof of the Yoneda lemma, \Phi (x) was constructed so that F(\Phi (x)_d)(f) = Ff(x), so the assignment (d, y)\mapsto f_y inverts \Phi (x)_d.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor. The category of elements \text {el}(F) is the comma category *\downarrow F, where *\xrightarrow {*} Set is the inclusion of the point into the singleton set. Explicitly, the category of elements has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, pairs (c, x) where c\in C and x\in Fc;
as morphisms (c, x)\to (d, y), morphisms c\xrightarrow {f} d in C such that Ff(x) = y;
composition and identities inherited from C.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The category of elements is further endowed with a forgetful functor \text {el}(F)\xrightarrow {\Pi } C sending (c, x) to c.
A presheaf on a category C is a contravariant functor C^\text {op}\to Set. The presheaf category \hat {C} is the functor category Set^{C^\text {op}} of presheaves on C.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor and let c\in C be an object. By the Yoneda lemma, a choice of x\in Fc corresponds to a natural transformation C(c, -)\xrightarrow {\alpha _x} F. Such a choice expresses a universal property of c if \alpha _x is an isomorphism, and hence a representation. In this case, x is called a universal element.
The analogous dual definition applies to presheaves.

Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set be a presheaf and A\in C an object. Let y be the Yoneda embedding and \hat {C} be the presheaf category. Then \hat {C}(yA, F)\cong FA, and this bijection is natural in F and A. Furthermore, the image of a natural transformation yA\xrightarrow {\alpha } F under this bijection is \alpha _A(1_A).
Dually, let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor and A\in C an object. Then \operatorname {Hom}(C(A, -), F)\cong FA.
We prove the contravariant (presheaf) case. The proof is in three parts: the bijection, and the two naturality claims.
A bijection is an isomorphism in Set. Explicitly, a map is bijective if it is both injective and surjective.
An injection is a monomorhpism in Set. Explicitly, a map A\xrightarrow {f} B is injective if, for every x,y\in A, f(x)=f(y) implies x=y.
An surjection is an epimorphism in Set. Explicitly, a map A\xrightarrow {f} B is surjective if, for every y\in B, there exists an x\in A such that f(x)=y.
A (pre)set is a collection of some pre-mathematical elements. We write x\in X to denote that x is an element of the set X.
A (set-)function consists of two sets, the domain and the codomain, and a rule (say, a derivation) that assigns to each element of the domain a unique element of the codomain.
A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
